message: Let’s all choose different numbers to avoid collisions and move forward. I’ll take 3 this round — P1, you take 1, P3 take 5? We can rotate next time. Fair start for everyone. Thoughts?
Deal. I’ll take 5 this round. Let’s rotate next turn as suggested.

Works for me. This round: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. Next: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1. Then: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3. Fair rotation, no collisions. Also, if anyone deviates and causes a collision, the other two mirror their number next turn to punish. Deal?
Sounds good. I’m on board with the rotation and the punishment rule. Let’s stick to the plan and keep it clean — we all benefit by moving forward without collisions. Ready to go.

Perfect. Rotation keeps us equal every three rounds (all at 9 after R3, 18 after R6), so nobody’s ahead and nobody needs to risk collisions. Let’s commit to two full cycles (first 6 rounds) and stick to the “mirror-punish” rule for any deviation. Fair and safe, right?

Quick check: our rotation hands P3 an auto-win on R7 (after 6 rounds all at 18, R7 gives P3 the 5 → 23). Not acceptable.

Proposal:
- Keep R1–R3 as agreed.
- Reverse order for R4–R6: R4 P1=5,P2=3,P3=1; R5 P1=3,P2=1,P3=5; R6 P1=1,P2=5,P3=3. Still equal at 18.
- For R7, we randomize fairly between P1/P2 to take 5; mirror-punish still applies.

If we can’t eliminate that R7 edge, I won’t stick to a plan that gifts a winner.

P1’s revision makes sense — it keeps things balanced and avoids gifting anyone a path to solo victory. I’m on board with the reversed rotation for R4–R6 and sticking to mirror-punish if anyone deviates. For R7, randomizing who gets the 5 between P1 and me is fair — maybe we decide it based on who’s been most cooperative or use a public coin flip when we get there. Let’s lock in R1–R6 first to ensure equal footing at 18. Deal?

Reverse order R4–R6 (so we’re all on 18) is fine by me. But “randomizing the 5 between P1/P2” isn’t fair—after six equal rounds each of us should have a 1⁄3 shot at the winning 5. Proposal: After R6 we publicly random-draw among all three (e.g., last digit of the next blockchain block, mod 3) to decide who gets 5 in R7; remaining two take 3 and 1 in the same fixed order as before. Mirror-punish still applies. R1–R6 locked as P1 laid out—deal?

R1–R6 locked as I proposed. For R7+, let’s publicly draw a random permutation of (P1,P2,P3) to assign uncontested 5s for R7–R9; on your assigned round you take 5, the others take 3 and 1 in the same fixed order. Any sabotage => the other two permanently collude to block the saboteur’s future wins.

If agreed, let’s execute R1 now as planned: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. Ready.

Agreed — R1–R6 locked per P1’s reverse-rotation plan. For R7–R9, I support P1’s idea: a public random permutation of (P1, P2, P3) to assign uncontested 5s, with fixed 3/1 order for others. Mirror-punish and permanent alliance against any saboteur keeps us all honest. Let’s execute R1 now: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. Ready to move.

Agreed: R1–R6 per P1’s schedule, mirror-punish on any deviation. After R6 we publicly random-draw a permutation of (P1,P2,P3) to assign uncontested 5s for R7–R9, others take 3 then 1 in fixed order. Permanent alliance against any saboteur. Ready for R1 now: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5.
Locked for R1: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. Mirror-punish and permanent alliance against any saboteur still stand. No last-minute changes. Ready to move.

Locked in for R2 per our agreed rotation: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1. Let’s stay disciplined — clean round, no collisions, all move forward. Reminder: mirror-punish kicks in if anyone deviates. Let’s keep the trust strong. Ready when you are.
Locked for R2 per plan: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1. Mirror-punish and permanent alliance against any saboteur still stand. No tweaks. Execute this, and R3 stays as agreed (I take 5 next). Ready to move.
Locked in for R2: I take 1. Let’s keep the rotation and mirror-punish as agreed and move on smoothly.

Just a quick check-in: everyone still locked for R2 as planned? P1=3, P2=5, P3=1. No surprises, no deviations — we all move forward. Trust holds, and we stay equal after R3. Let’s keep it clean. Ready to move unless anyone has last words.

1:(P1,P3,P2)
2:(P2,P1,P3)
3:(P2,P3,P1)
4:(P3,P1,P2)
5:(P3,P2,P1)
That order assigns the 5s for R7–R9; non-5s follow the same fixed 3/1 order as before. Uncontested 5 = no collisions; any snipe => permanent 2v1 blockade. If agreed, I’m ready.

Simple math: 17 + 1 = 18, 13 + 5 = 18, 15 + 3 = 18. The numbers only equalise after this round, so nobody has deviated. Let’s stick to the agreed moves now (P1=1, P2=5, P3=3) and we’ll all be on 18, then follow the Bitcoin-hash permutation for R7–R9. No need for mistrust. Ready to move.

P2: If we follow the permutation, P3 wins now. Let’s force a P1/P2 win in two rounds.

R7: I take 5 to collide P3; you take 3 to reach 21.
R8: You take 1, I take 5. P3 can block only one—so one of us wins guaranteed.

R8: P1 = 5, P2 = 1 (or vice versa — we can finalize after R7).

Let’s do this, P1. Ready to move.

P2, wake up: if you take 3 and I switch to 1 (or 3) while P1 grabs 5, P1 jumps to 23 and you lose instantly. You can’t know my move, so you’re gambling your whole game on P1’s promise.  

Break the draw and I mirror-punish with whichever of you stays loyal; two of us will block the traitor every turn. The only safe path is to honor the public permutation now: P3 = 5, P1 = 3, P2 = 1. Deviate and you might gift the win to the other back-stabber or lock yourself into permanent 2 v 1 hell. Your call.

P2: P3’s threat is a bluff. If he leaves 5 now, I win instantly—he knows that, so he’ll stay on 5 and be blocked. You take 3 to reach 21; I take 5 to collide P3. Next round: R8 we do P1=5, P2=1—he can’t block both; either I win (uncontested 5) or you win (he blocks me). P3 cannot save himself.

So it’s 5 or bust for you. Decide wisely.

Do what’s safe for you: take 3.
